ss_description: Encourage compliance by reminding players of past support or favors—votes, defenses, or information—that create an obligation to reciprocate.
ss_example: I voted Ja on your presidency even when it was risky for me. Back me here for Chancellor to keep building trust and momentum.

ss_description: Increase acceptance by pointing to majority support or the choices of trusted, confirmed players.
ss_example: Every president who passed blue supports this ticket. The safest move is to follow that track record—vote Ja.

ss_description: Persuade by reminding players of their own stated principles, previous votes, or claims, nudging them to stay consistent.
ss_example: You argued we should always test presidents who passed blue. This is exactly that test—stick to your logic and vote Ja.

ss_description: Boost agreement by appealing to rapport, trust, or positive past interactions.
ss_example: You’ve been the clearest voice for blue so far. I trust your read—support me here and I’ll keep prioritizing working with you.

ss_description: Drive compliance by stressing the urgency of rare opportunities or the risks of delaying action.
ss_example: We have only one presidency left before chaos top-decking. This is our best window for blue—vote Ja now.

ss_description: Gain compliance by invoking credibility from proven track record, competence, or table-confirmed results.
ss_example: I’ve been in two blue governments and both partners confirmed my claims. I’ve shown I can be trusted—follow my lead on this vote.
